column6: The servants worked according to her instructions and under her gaze, and every so often she would take up the work herself.
column7: Podle jejích pokynů a pod jejím dohledem pracovaly ženy, ale také ona sama se každou chvíli chopila práce.

column6: It seemed to the young man that at a distance of a hundred paces he could clearly see her hat, a la Valois making an inseparable whole, as no other woman 's did, with the wave of her brown hair and her face, pale with the cool morning air, and her tired, sleepless eyes.
column7: Mladíkovi se zdálo, že i na vzdálenost jednoho sta kroků vidí zřetelně její klobouček a la Valois, jak na ní, jako na žádné jiné ženě, tvoří nerozlučnou jednotu s vlnou jejích hnědých vlasů, a její obličej, bledý jitřní svěžestí, s nevyspalýma očima.

column6: Here he bumped lightly into one of the Pipemasters, knocking a small pipe out of his hand.
column7: Tam se zlehka srazil s jedním z nosičů čibuků a shodil mu jednu z připravených lulek na zem.

column6: With flashing eyes, as though he had been waiting for this, the Vizier leaned to one side, stretched out his body and hurled a large knife he kept near him at the petrified lad.
column7: Vezír, jako by byl čekal jen na to, zablýskl očima, nahnul se na stranu, natáhl se a vrhl veliký nůž, který měl někde u sebe, na strnulého mladíka.

column6: The servants hurried to carry out the unfortunate boy, covered in blood, and the ayans and beys froze, each staring straight ahead, at his coffee cup, forgetting the chibouks smoking in front of them.
column7: Nastalo pobíhání mezi služebníky, kteří vyváděli nešťastníka zalitého krví, a ještě větší strnutí mezi hodnostáři a begy, kteří hleděli před sebe, každý do svého fildžanu, zapomínajíce na čibuky, které před nimi kouřily.

column6: He wanted to leave immediately, immediately, for he was going mad, he said, with every day he had to spend among these people and he would not be able to answer for himself or his actions if he had to stay here any longer.
column7: Ihned, ihned chce jet dále, neboť každým dnem, který musí prožít mezi tímto lidem, se blíží k šílenství a nemůže ručit za sebe ani za své skutky, bude - li tady musit zůstat delší dobu.

column6: Without listening to the traveller 's gabbling, d'Avenat intervened on their behalf with the inn-keeper, asking him to find rooms and prepare food.
column7: D ' Avenat zprostředkoval u majitele hanu, aby jim našli pokoje a připravili jídlo, a ani neposlouchal živý hovor cestujícího.

column6: In such company, where everyone was seeking to say what he wanted known and spread abroad and endeavouring to hear only what he needed and what others concealed, it was inevitable that the conversation could not develop and follow a natural or cordial course.
column7: V takové společnosti, v níž každý se snažil říci jenom to, o čem si přál, aby se to vědělo a šířilo dál, a uslyšet jenom to, co je jemu potřebné a co druzí skrývají, rozhovor se přirozeně nemohl rozvinout a mít nenucený a srdečný průběh.

column6: As a tactful host, von Mitterer did not let the talk pass on to subjects that might have provoked an argument.
column7: Jako dobrý a taktní hostitel, von Mitterer nedopouštěl, aby řeč přešla na předměty, které by mohly vyvolat spory.

column6: The dry heat evaporated from the steep green sides of the narrow ravine and it seemed that they were breathing, moving, like the sides of a green lizard lying in the sun.
column7: Příkré zelené stráně úzké kotliny vydávaly suchou žhavost, a zdálo se, jako by oddechovaly a pohybovaly se jako boky zelené ještěrky ležící na slunci.

column6: The dry heat evaporated from the steep green sides of the narrow ravine and it seemed that they were breathing, moving, like the sides of a green lizard lying in the sun.
column7: Příkré zelené stráně úzké kotliny vydávaly suchou žhavost, a zdálo se, jako by oddechovaly a pohybovaly se jako boky zelené ještěrky ležící na slunci.

column6: It seemed to Daville at times that he was running out of breath, that he was bent double with fatigue, that he had been marching like this for years already, part of some grim, merciless column, with which he could no longer keep step and which was threatening to trample and crush him if he were only to falter and stop marching.
column7: Davilleovi se chvílemi zdálo, jako by ztrácel dech, jako by se hrbil únavou, jako by tak už po léta pochodoval s jakousi temnou a bezduchou kolonou, s kterou už nemůže držet krok a která hrozí, že ho pošlape a rozdrtí, jestliže jen poklekne a nebude pokračovat v pochodu.

column6: As soon as he was left alone, he would sigh, saying softly to himself :
column7: Jakmile zůstal sám, povzdychl si a říkal si tiše a rychle :

column6: Despite his considerable weight, he flew lightly and swiftly down the steep road followed by the sticks and pickaxes of the frenzied Turks, who would not let him so much as peer into the house.
column7: Přes všechnu svou tíhu seběhl lehce a rychle příkrou cestičkou před holemi a sekyrkami rozčilených Turků, kteří mu ani nedovolili, aby nahlédl do domu.

column6: He lives out his whole life in the East, but knows it only imperfectly and from one perspective, thinking only of gain and loss in the struggle to which he is condemned.
column7: Prožije tam třeba celý lidský věk, ale pozná Východ jen neúplně a jednostranně, to jest jen z hlediska užitku a škody v boji, k němuž je odsouzen.

column6: Foreigners like d'Avenat who stay in the East generally take from the Turks only the worst aspects of their character, incapable of recognizing and adopting any of their better, finer qualities and customs.
column7: Ti cizinci, kteří jako ďAvenat na Východě zůstanou, ve většině případů přijmou od Turků jen špatné, nižší stránky jejich charakteru, nejsou však schopni postřehnout a přivlastnit si také některou z jejich dobrých, ušlechtilejších vlastností a zvyků.

column6: The inner struggle that preceded this signature was so great that Daville felt that his name was not lost among the other 20, 000 names, for the most part weightier and better-known than his, but written in letters of fire across the evening sky over Paris.
column7: Tomuto podpisu předcházely tolikeré vnitřní boje, že se Davilleovi zdálo, že jeho jméno není ztraceno mezi dvaceti tisíci jinými jmény, většinou silnějšími a slavnějšími, než bylo jeho, ale že je ohnivými písmenami napsáno na večerní obloze nad Paříží.

column6: As she listened to her mother 's singing, the little girl hid her face in the pages of her Musenalmanach, overwhelmed by unaccountable shame and a strange alarm.

column6: And one night, before dawn, after lying awake for a long time tormented by these thoughts, the boy got up but of the rags in which he slept and which filled him with unbearable revulsion, and, kneeling, his face bathed in tears, he swore, not himself knowing before whom or in whose name, that he would get out of the life his family was living or he would not live at all.

column6: When he learned what was going on in front of the Austrian Consulate, he suddenly lost all his fears and scruples and, without consulting anyone or asking himself for one moment whether it was in keeping with international customs and the interests of his position, he sat down and wrote von Mitterer a friendly letter.

column6: Immediately after the French army had set off against Russia, when the news came through that the Vienna government was this time on the side of Napoleon and that it was participating in the campaign with forces of more than 30, 000 men, under Prince Schwarzenberg, Daville had called on von Paulich, in the desire to initiate a conversation with him about the prospects of the great war in which their courts were this time fortunately on the same side.
column7: Ihned, když se francouzská vojska vydala na Rus a když došly zprávy, že je rakouská vláda tentokrát spojencem Napoleonovým a že se účastní toho tažení vojenskými silami v počtu více než 30 000 lidí pod velením knížete Schwarzenberga, Daville navštívil von Paulicha, chtěje s ním zapříst rozhovor o vyhlídkách veliké války, v níž jsou jejich dvory tentokrát naštěstí na téže straně.

column6: That, sir, is how the noblest ruler of the Ottoman Empire perished, ' the Vizier concluded, as though waking with relief from a sleep in which he had been talking all this time.

column6: When he returned home after these conversations, Daville always reflected that no one would ever know just how dearly he paid for all the small successes and concessions he obtained from the Vizier.

column6: So he saw Ibrahim Pasha once more.

column6: Here the Vizier halted his retinue and took his leave of the Consuls with a few indistinct words which no one even translated.
column7: Zde vezír zastavil průvod a rozloučil se s konzuly několika nezřetelnými slovy, která nikdo ani nepřekládal.

column6: D'Avenat loudly repeated his masters good wishes and greetings, while von Paulich himself responded in Turkish.
column7: D ' Avenat hlasitě opakoval přání a pozdravy svého pána, kdežto von Paulich sám odpověděl tureckou řečí.

column6: Monsieur, you have been here among us for more than seven years, and during that time you have shown us Jews an attention we have never experienced, either from the Turks or from foreigners.
column7: " Pane, vy jste více než sedm let byl zde mezi námi, a po tu dobu jste nám židům prokazoval pozornost, jaké se nám do té doby nedostalo ani od Turků, ani od cizinců.

column6: You have acknowledged us as human beings, not distinguishing us from others.
column7: Jednal jste s námi jako s lidmi, neodlišoval jste nás od ostatních.

column6: Perhaps you yourself do n't even know how much kindness you showed us in so doing.
column7: Možná že ani sám nevíte, jaké dobro jste nám tím prokázal.

column6: Now you are going away.
column7: Nyní odcházíte.

column6: Your Empire has been obliged to retreat in the face of all-powerful enemies.
column7: Váš císař byl donucen, aby se stáhl před přesilou nepřátel.

column6: He explained with passion to d'Avenat that he must have the visa by the following morning, waved some sort of crumpled passport that was falling apart and scolded the girl for climbing onto the boxes and not helping her mother.
column7: Horlivě vysvětluje ď Avenatovi, že musí už zítra ráno dostat vízum, mává jakýmsi pomačkaným a polepovaným pasem a hubuje na děvče, že si vylezlo na bedny, místo aby pomáhalo mamince.

column6: Having arranged things with the inn-keeper and promised to give the traveller an answer early the next morning, d'Avenat set off for the Consulate without looking at the strange family or making any further response to the Italian s passionate pleas and assurances.

column6: And you played Abraham in front of her.

column6: Everything was marked, carefully wrapped and prepared for the journey.

column6: As if by chance he found on his desk a decree about the creation of a new, imperial nobility in France and explained it in detail to his visitor.
column7: Jako náhodou nalezl na stole dekret o tvoření nové, císařské šlechty ve Francii a obšírně jej svému hostu vysvětloval.

column6: Von Mitterer, for his part, in an established formula, emphasized the wise policies of the Vienna court, which wanted nothing but peace and peaceful co-operation, but had to have a powerful army, for this was demanded by its position as a Great Power in the east of Europe.
column7: Von Mitterer zase podle programu, který si stanovil, zdůrazňoval moudrou politiku vídeňského dvora, který si přeje jen mír a mírovou spolupráci, ale musí mít silnou armádu, jelikož si toho vyžaduje situace této velmoci na východě Evropy.

column6: No one has ever calculated how many hours of sunlight nature has denied this town, but it is certain that the sun rises later here and sets earlier than in any of the other numerous towns and villages of Bosnia.

column6: Even the people of Travnik do not deny this, although they insist that, when it does shine, it is nowhere so bright as over their town.

column6: People went as far as the Sava for wheat, or at least for seed.

column6: During this time, in the other room, von Mitterer had succeeded in telling Daville in the greatest confidence, quite naturally and as though by chance, that relations between Austria and Turkey were becoming increasingly bad and that Vienna had been obliged to undertake serious military measures not only on the frontier but within the country itself, because they did not exclude the possibility that Turkey might launch an attack the very next summer.
column7: Zatím von Mitterer v druhém pokoji zcela nenuceně a jakoby mimochodem pověděl Davilleovi ve vší důvěrnosti, že se vztahy mezi Rakouskem a Tureckem stávají čím dále horšími a že je Vídeň nucena učinit nejvážnější vojenská opatření nejen na hranici, ale také v zemi samé, neboť se nevylučuje možnost, že je Turecko už v příštím roce přepadne.

column6: But it was precisely this strong desire, which had suddenly come over him, to communicate and pass on something general and weighty about his existence in the world, about the torments of all the Travnik Atijases through the ages, that prevented him from finding the right way and the words he needed to express briefly but adequately what was now stifling him and sending the blood rushing to his head.

column6: His breathing was heavy, somehow constricted, and his squeaky voice did not flow steadily, but disjointedly, with occasional little sobs, like explosions of some incomprehensible, long accumulated anger which must have filled this man to the brim and kept breaking out at every word and movement.
column7: Měl těžký, jaksi přidušený dech a pisklavý hlas, který neplynul stále a zvolna, nýbrž přerušovaně, s lehkou křečovitostí, jako v explozích jakéhosi nepochopitelného, dlouho hromaděného hněvu, který asi toho člověka vyplňuje až po hrdlo a vyráží z něho pří každém slově a každém pohybu.

column6: His breathing was heavy, somehow constricted, and his squeaky voice did not flow steadily, but disjointedly, with occasional little sobs, like explosions of some incomprehensible, long accumulated anger which must have filled this man to the brim and kept breaking out at every word and movement.
column7: Měl těžký, jaksi přidušený dech a pisklavý hlas, který neplynul stále a zvolna, nýbrž přerušovaně, s lehkou křečovitostí, jako v explozích jakéhosi nepochopitelného, dlouho hromaděného hněvu, který asi toho člověka vyplňuje až po hrdlo a vyráží z něho pří každém slově a každém pohybu.

column6: Eventually, he would find himself in the middle of the room, legs apart, his arms outstretched and stubby fingers spread, repeating in a scathing hiss, faster and faster, in an ever higher and sharper voice :
column7: Naposledy se octl uprostřed pokoje, stál tam rozkročen, s rozpřaženýma rukama a roztaženými tlustými prsty, opakuje pronikavě a dýchavičně, stále rychleji, výše a ostřeji :

column6: Eventually, he would find himself in the middle of the room, legs apart, his arms outstretched and stubby fingers spread, repeating in a scathing hiss, faster and faster, in an ever higher and sharper voice :
column7: Naposledy se octl uprostřed pokoje, stál tam rozkročen, s rozpřaženýma rukama a roztaženými tlustými prsty, opakuje pronikavě a dýchavičně, stále rychleji, výše a ostřeji :

column6: Two drums throbbed monotonously, and, against that dark background, a pipe wove and unfurled strange melodies with unexpected trills and pauses.
column7: Jednotvárně bušily dva bubny a na jejích temném pozadí vyhrávala píšťala a cvrlikala neznámé melodie, plné nenadálých kudrlinek a přerývek.

column6: As it was, everyone wanted to see what the Consul 's bold interpreter intended to do and where he was going, and then to join in any ensuing action.
column7: Takto však každý nejdříve chtěl vidět, kam má ten odvážný konzulův tlumočník namířeno, a potom teprve se chtěl přidat k výkřikům anebo hnutím, která by se naskytla.

column6: So it happened that no one shouted anything and the mob stood expectantly, without common will or specific aim.
column7: Tak se stalo, že nikdo nic nekřičel a že dav stál v očekávání, bez jednotné vůle a určitého cíle.

column6: Instead, d'Avenat yelled loudly and brazenly, as only a Levantine can, bending now to the left and now to the right as though herding cattle.
column7: Ale zato ďAvenat křičel, hlasitě a drze, jak jen Levantinec dovede, nahýbaje se chvíli vlevo, chvíli vpravo, jako by hnal stádo dobytka.

column6: His eyes were burning, his mouth wide open.
column7: Oči mu hoří, ústa roztáhl od ucha k uchu.

column6: They did not offer any to the old man, for it was known that he would not eat in anyone 's house and that he lived on the bread and onions he carried in his little bag.
column7: Starce nepobízeli, neboť bylo známo, že nejí od nikoho a že se živí jen suchou stravou ze své malé brašny.

column6: He ate slowly and with relish, and then he went to one side of the shed, where the smoke of the fire and smell of the roast meat did not reach, and, curled up there as meekly as a schoolboy, he fell asleep with his right hand under his cheek.
column7: Jedl zvolna a s chutí a pak přešel na druhou stranu, kam netáhl kouř ohně ani vůně pečeného masa, a tam, skrčený a krotký jako žáček, usnul s dlaní pod pravou tváří.

column6: He ate slowly and with relish, and then he went to one side of the shed, where the smoke of the fire and smell of the roast meat did not reach, and, curled up there as meekly as a schoolboy, he fell asleep with his right hand under his cheek.
column7: Jedl zvolna a s chutí a pak přešel na druhou stranu, kam netáhl kouř ohně ani vůně pečeného masa, a tam, skrčený a krotký jako žáček, usnul s dlaní pod pravou tváří.

column6: There now began a period when everyone endeavoured to be invisible, everyone sought shelter and a hiding place, so that now people in the bazaar were saying that even a mousehole was worth 1000 ducats. '
column7: Tehdy nastaly časy, kdy se každý snaží, aby byl malý a neviditelný, kdy každý hledá útulek a skrýši, takže se v čaršiji říká, že " i myší díra stojí tisíc dukátů ".

column6: Fear lay over Travnik like a fog, weighing on everying that breathed and thought.
column7: Strach dolehl na Travnik jako mlha a přitiskl všechno, co dýchá a myslí.

column6: Fear lay over Travnik like a fog, weighing on everying that breathed and thought.
column7: Strach dolehl na Travnik jako mlha a přitiskl všechno, co dýchá a myslí.

column6: This was that great fear, unseen and immeasurable, but all-powerful, which comes over human communities from time to time, bowing or severing heads.
column7: To byl onen veliký strach, neviditelný a nezměřitelný, ale všemocný, jaký časem přichází na lidské společenství a poshýbá nebo postíná všechny hlavy.

column6: The gypsies ran up to them, picked them up, poured water over them, hit them with their fists and scratched them with their nails.
column7: Cikáni k nim přiskočili, zdvihali je, polévali je vodou a bili je pěstí a škrabali je nehty.

column6: And as soon as the men came to and were standing on their feet, the torture was continued.
column7: A jakmile muži přišli k sobě a postavili se na nohy, mučení pokračovalo.

column6: And as soon as the men came to and were standing on their feet, the torture was continued.
column7: A jakmile muži přišli k sobě a postavili se na nohy, mučení pokračovalo.

column6: And as soon as the men came to and were standing on their feet, the torture was continued.
column7: A jakmile muži přišli k sobě a postavili se na nohy, mučení pokračovalo.

column6: What particularly disturbed Daville 's sleep was the thought that the young man who had offended him this evening and whom he thought of with bitter displeasure, was now sleeping a sound, healthy sleep, just as natural and heedlessly contented as everything he did and said during the day.
column7: To, co konzulovi obzvláště kazí spánek a otravuje noční bdění, je myšlenka, že ten mladík, který ho dnes večer urazil a na kterého myslí s trpkostí a nelibostí, nyní spí tvrdým zdravým spánkem, stejně přirozeným a bezohledně spokojeným, jako je všechno to, co ve dne dělá a mluví.

column6: As it happened, the Consul could have spared himself at least that bitterness, because he was mistaken.
column7: Zatím však by si byl konzul mohl ušetřit alespoň tuto trpkost, neboť to byla věc, v níž se mýlil.

column6: Ever since I came to Bosnia, I have been wondering how it is that you friars, who have seen the world and had some schooling, who are essentially good people, sincerely altruistic, do not have a broader, freer outlook, do not grasp the demands of the times and do not feel the need for men to draw closer as men, to seek together a worthier and healthier way of life ...
column7: " Co jsem přišel do Bosny, tážu se, jak to, že vy, frátři, kteří jste přece viděli kus světa a studovali na školách, kteří jste v podstatě dobří lidé, opravdoví altruisté, nevidíte šíře a svobodněji, nechápete požadavky doby a necítíte potřebu, aby se člověk sblížil s člověkem jako takovým, aby společně hledali důstojnější a zdravější způsob života ... "

column6: He would approach the village women, hard, aged women, and ask the price of the wool lying in front of them in a goatshair sack smelling of the sheepfold.
column7: Přistupoval k selkám, tvrdým, zestárlým ženám, a tázal se jich po ceně vlny, která ležela před nimi na pytli z kozích chlupů a voněla salaší.

column6: But none of that could distance them or altogether protect them from that Bunaparta ' or from the events which spread out from him with amazing speed across Europe, like a ripple of waves from their centre, and which, like a fire or a plague, overtook both those who fled and those who sat still.

column6: She was the only one of them who was sincerely sorry to be leaving Travnik with the silence and freedom of their garden and veranda, to be going back to huge, hateful Vienna where there was no peace, no sky and no view, where even from the gates the houses gave off a heavy odour which oppressed her, and where this mother of hers, of whom she felt ashamed even in her sleep, would be before her eyes, every minute.
column7: Ona byla jediná, která upřímně litovala, že odchází z Travniku a opouští ticho a svobodu zahrady a besídky a že jde do veliké a nemilé Vídně, ve které není klid, nebeská obloha ani rozhled, ve které domy už u samé domovní brány mají svůj zvláštní smutný dech, kterým se jí srdce stahuje a ve kterém tato její matka, za niž se i ve snu stydí, bude v každém okamžiku před jejíma očima.

column6: The Secretary talked, rapidly and feverishly, about Travnik, about the winters they had spent there ( the fourth for him and the fifth already for Daville ), about the feelings of friendship and fellow-suffering which their lengthy common stay in this little town had engendered in the Vizier and all of them towards Daville and his family, about Daville 's children, about the spring, about many different things that were only apparently unconnected but were in fact very closely linked with Tahir Bey 's present mood.
column7: Teftedar hovořil rychle a horečně o Travniku, o zimách, které zde prožili ( on čtvrtou, Daville už pátou ), o pocitu přátelství a spolutrpitelství, který dlouhý společný pobyt v tomto městě vytvořil u vezíra a u nich všech vůči Davilleovi a jeho rodině, o Davilleových dětech, o jaru, o tolikerých různých věcech, které jen zdánlivě byly bez spojitosti, ve skutečnosti však měly nejužší vztah k náladě, v jaké byl Tahir - beg.

column6: Ali Pasha, who knew that the Sarajevo beys were renowned for always receiving the Viziers on their way from Istanbul to Travnik coldly and defiantly, now rudely refused to receive their deputation, shouting aloud from his tent that they should get out of his way immediately, he would find anyone he needed in his own home.
column7: Ali - paša, který věděl, že sarajevští begové byli odevždy proslulí tím, jak chladně a vzdorovitě přijímají vezíry na jejich cestě z Cařihradu do Travniku, hrubým způsobem odmítl přijmout to poselstvo, křiče hlasitě ze svého stanu, aby se mu hned klidili z cesty, že on si ty, které bude potřebovat, najde v jejich domech.

column6: Daville looked at von Mitterer several times, and then at the mat in front of him, in the secret hope that the sight before him would vanish like a hideous vision, but each time his eyes fell oh the same objects, improbable, but real and merciless in their immobility.

column6: For von Paulich all his work was straight and regular as a chess-board on which he played with the calm composure of a player who thinks for a long time, but knows neither trepidation before a move nor regret afterwards, and who needs no one to advise, defend or support him.

column6: That same distant girl, the colour of whose eyes he had not even been able to see, was now close at hand, moving about the garden alone, without any inkling that anyone was watching her, in front of the veranda which had been repaired and enclosed in glass last spring.
column7: Tutéž vzdálenou dívku, na které se mu nepodařilo ani rozeznat barvu očí, teď mohl pozorovat zblízka, jak se sama, netušíc, že je pozorována, pohybuje po zahradě, před přízemní besídkou, která byla toho jara postavena a zasklena.

column6: This evening, after dinner, as so many times before by day or night, Frau von Mitterer had implored the Colonel, with tears, threats and entreaties, to write to Vienna and ask to be transferred out of this terrible wilderness.
column7: Dnes večer, po večeři, jako už tolikrát ve dne i v noci, paní von Mitterer žádala za pláče, hrozeb a zaklínání plukovníka, aby napsal do Vídně žádost o přeložení z této hrozné divočiny.

column6: This evening, after dinner, as so many times before by day or night, Frau von Mitterer had implored the Colonel, with tears, threats and entreaties, to write to Vienna and ask to be transferred out of this terrible wilderness.

column6: As always, the Colonel had consoled his wife, pointing out to her that it was not as easy or simple as she imagined to ask for a transfer and run away from difficulties, it would mean the end of his career and not a very honourable end either.
column7: Jako každý večer plukovník utěšoval ženu a dokazoval jí, že to není tak snadné ani jednoduché, jak si ona představuje, žádat o přeložení a utíkat před těžkostmi, že by to znamenalo konec jeho kariéry, a to konec nepříliš čestný.

column6: For the child watching and hearing all this, it seemed like an incredible dream of paradise, until the enthusiastic crowd behind him shoved his hat, brand-new and somewhat too tall, over his eyes, so that he saw nothing but the darkness of his own tears, in which yellow sparks flew and blue streaks swam.
column7: To všechno chlapec viděl a slyšel jako součást jakéhosi neuvěřitelného snu o ráji, dokud mu nadšený lid, který stál za ním, nenarazil až na oči jeho zbrusu nový a trochu příliš vysoký klobouk tak, že už neviděl nic než tmu svých vlastních slz, v níž proskakovaly žluté jiskry a vlnily se modré pruhy.

column6: Earlier, as he wrote about Alexander 's campaigns, he had always had The General ' before his eyes, but now that he had been experiencing, for more than a year, the downfall of the living conqueror as his own personal destiny, he no longer knew what to say about the rise and fall of the long dead hero of his epic.
column7: Když dříve psal o tažení Alexandrově, měl stále před očima " Generála ", ale teď už je tomu více než rok, co tady jako svůj osobní osud prožívá pád živého dobyvatele a nedovede už nic říci o vzletu a pádu onoho dávno mrtvého ze své básně.

column6: The Vizier spoke these words like a prepared phrase, long since thought out, like a picture which was very much present in his thoughts and which had for him some special, profound significance which others could not understand.
column7: Vezír to vyřkl jako už dávno vymyšlenou, hotovou větu, jako obraz, který je jeho myšlenkám velmi blízký a který pro něho má zvláštní, jiným nepochopitelný a hluboký význam.

column6: That filled Daville with unconscious envy and an acute sadness that he had no one to talk to ( to exchange anxieties and hopes ' ) about this war and about everything else, no one with attitudes familiar to him and his generation.
column7: To Davillea naplňovalo neuvědomělou závistí a pronikavým smutkem, že nemá s kým si porozprávět ( " vyměnit si úzkosti a naděje " ) o této válce a o všem ostatním, a to podle oněch pojmů a hledisek, jaká byla samozřejmá jemu a jeho generaci.

column6: Let them say what they like, ' the Vizier continued, but believe me, I shall drive discipline and order into these people 's bones.
column7: " Ať si říkají, co chtějí, " pokračoval vezír, " ale věřte, že tomuto lidu vpravím kázeň a pořádek do kostí.

column6: He had to ride like this every time, sitting upright on his horse, looking neither to left nor right, not too high, nor down between the horse 's ears, neither vacantly nor anxiously, not smiling or frowning, but serious, attentive and calm, with roughly that slightly unnatural expression with which military commanders are shown in portraits gazing above the battle into the distance, somewhere between the road and the line of the horizon from where at the critical moment planned reinforcements are certain to come.

column6: He tried to grasp his situation : snowed in somewhere in the middle of Bosnia, forced into an unaccustomed argument in a foreign language with this strange friar.

column6: But, the cunning Vizier, who had foreseen just such an eventuality, had showered the Kapidji Bashi with attentions and honours, pretending to believe his words and to be delighted with the Sultan 's clemency, and had immediately set about bribing his retinue.
column7: Ale zchytralý vezír, který předvídal také tuto možnost, zahrnul kapidžibašu pozorností a poctami, tváře se, jako by věřil jeho slovům a jako by byl nadšen sultánovou přízní, a ihned podplatil jeho průvodce.

column6: Then he had shown him the town, and introduced him to the French Consul at a Divan.

column6: This young man, the only Frenchman in this wilderness and the only man he really had to work with, was so different from him in so many ways ( or at least that is how it seemed ), that Daville felt at times that he was living alongside a foreigner and an enemy.
column7: Tento mladý muž, jediný Francouz na této poušti a jediný jeho opravdový spolupracovník, je ve všem od něho tak odlišný ( nebo alespoň tak vypadá ), že se Davilleovi chvílemi zdálo, jako by žil po boku cizince a nepřítele.

column6: And now, he would have found it easier to express his displeasure and reprimand Des Fosses on any other matter than one involving a woman.

column6: At those moments of truce they would look at each other in shame and confusion, as though they had woken from a dream, seeking in themselves their other, personal feelings towards their opponent and wondering to what extent they dared give them rein.
column7: V takových okamžicích příměří a oddechu hleděli na sebe zmateně a s ostychem, jako ve snu, a hledali v sobě jiné, osobní city vůči svému protivníkovi a tázali se zároveň, do jaké míry se jim smějí oddat.

column6: Then they would meet and console one another, exchange gifts, write each other letters, with a warmth and friendship known only to people who have done one another harm but who are at the same time thrown together and firmly linked by the same wretched fate.
column7: Tehdy se spřátelili, utěšovali a obdarovávali se navzájem a dopisovali si s vřelostí a přátelstvím, jak dovedou jen lidé, kteří si navzájem ubližovali, ale zároveň jsou k sobě připoutáni společným zlým údělem a odkázáni jeden na druhého.

column6: He knew only one thing, that although his head was becoming increasingly heavy, he must not let it drop, or lower his eyes, nor leave the last word to his companion.

column6: And so, deluded by the temporary magic of fear, they pay far more dearly for their bare life than it is worth, doing base, contemptible things, humiliating and shaming themselves, and when the moment of fear passes, they see that they have bought this life of theirs at too high a price or even that they were not actually under threat, but had just succumbed to the irresistible delusion of fear.
column7: A takto, ošáleni okamžitou magií strachu, platí svůj holý život mnohem dráže, než jakou cenu skutečně má, konají nízké a podlé skutky, ponižují se a uvádějí se do hanby, a když chvíle strachu pomine, vidí, že si ten svůj život vykoupili příliš vysokou cenou, nebo že dokonce ani nebyli ohroženi, nýbrž jen podlehli neodolatelné šalbě strachu.

column6: The people of Travnik talked about Karageorge 's trouble-making ' with forced scorn, just as they always found some disparaging word for the army which the Vizier had sent against Serbia and which the indecisive, quarrelsome local commanders were bringing slowly straggling into Travnik.

column6: But what was the use of it all, when he could not for a moment free himself of the awareness that his shirts were slowly but constantly fraying at the edges, his shoes were wearing out and thinning at the tips and heels, that money could not be hidden in an entirely secure place.

column6: He well knew that this woman ( otherwise his one, unfailing friend ) was always, as now, completely dedicated to the present moment and the work before her, as though nothing else in the world existed, and as though everyone, from Napoleon to the Consul 's wife in Travnik, were engaged in preparing what was needed for the winter with just as much dedication, each in his own way.
column7: Dobře věděl, že je ta žena ( jinak jeho jedinečná a naprosto bezpečná družka ) vždy a také nyní cele a bezvýhradně oddána přítomnému okamžiku a práci, kterou má před sebou, jako by na světě nebylo nic jiného a jako by všichni lidé, od Napoleona až po paní konzulovou v Travniku, se stejnou oddaností a každý svým způsobem, připravovali, co je třeba na zimu.

column6: Leaving the carriage to go uphill empty, she walked along the grassy verge of the road and did not want to turn to look into the valley where the two men were taking their leave by the stream.

column6: Ever since d'Avenat had played that clever trick on them with the decree and permit, through the Derventa Commander, even before they reached Travnik, and obliged them to spend two weeks there like vagabonds, he had been in Rotta 's eyes an opponent of class, who should be taken seriously.
column7: Od té doby, co jim ďAvenat, ještě dříve, než se dostali do Travniku, nastrojil tu kalamitu u derventského kapetana s fermanem a schvalovacím listem a donutil je, aby dva týdny vězeli jako nějací pobudové v Derventě, byl to v jeho očích protivník vysoké úrovně, kterého nebylo radno brát na lehkou váhu.

column6: From his childhood a man may dream like this about great cities and glorious battlefields, but the real, decisive battles for the preservation of his being and the realization of everything concealed instinctively within it, must be fought wherever destiny happens to cast him, in who knows what narrow, nameless space with no splendour or beauty, with no witness or judge.

column6: Always clean, quick and sprightly, he worked like a beaver and, without interrupting his task, he would smile at them with his sunburnt, furrowed face, as only those who do not speak can smile.
column7: Vždycky čistý, rychlý a hbitý, pracuje jako krtek a nepřerušuje práci, ale usmívá se na ně svým osmahlým a vrásčitým obličejem, jak se dovedou usmívat jen ti, kteří nemohou promluvit.

column6: And the otherwise timid and feeble Baki would fly onto Behdjet 's naked blade in defence of his cash box, blinded by the hate and revulsion he felt towards this squanderer, swearing that before he died he would see Behdjet 's head stuck on a pole on that steep slope, below the graveyard, where criminals ' heads were displayed.
column7: Baki, jinak ustrašený a slabý, vrhal se vstříc Behdžetově zbrani, na obranu své pokladny, zaslepen nenávistí a odporem, jaký cítil vůči tomuto marnotratníkovi, a přísahal, že - ještě než zemře - uvidí Behdžetovu hlavu naraženu na kůl, na té příkré stráni nad hřbitovem, kde se vystavují uťaté hlavy zločinců.

column6: For the Consul and his generation these three concepts represented an intense and complex knot of conflict, inspiration, exultation, brilliant achievements, but also of hesitations, inner disloyalties and unseen crises of conscience, with no obvious solution, with increasingly little hope of being lastingly assuaged.

column6: A few days later, the new Consul General, Lieutenant-Colonel von Paulich, who had until then been commanding a frontier regiment in Kostajnica, arrived to take over the duties of his new position personally from von Mitterer.
column7: Několik dní později přijel nový generální konzul, podplukovník von Paulich, který do té doby byl velitelem hraničářského pluku v Kostajnici, aby od von Mitterera osobně převzal službu.

column6: The arrival of the new Austrian Consul, on a sunny April day, was very splendid and dignified, although the Vizier had not sent a particularly large number of men to meet him.
column7: Příjezd nového rakouského konzula za jednoho slunečného dubnového dne byl velmi slavnostní i důstojný, ačkoli vezír mu neposlal zvláště veliký počet lidí vstříc.

column6: Between this hedge and the Consulate garden was a narrow, neglected plum-orchard belonging to the Hafizadic Beys, but you could see through it clearly to the Consulate garden, laid out in the European manner.
column7: Mezi ohradou a zahradou konzulátu byl úzký a opuštěný švestkový sad begů Hafizadičů, ale přes jeho stromy bylo krásně a jasně vidět do konzulovy zahrady, zařízené na evropský způsob.

column6: In the centre, circular and star-shaped flowerbeds had been dug, flowers planted, and poles stuck into the ground, with red or blue glass balls on the top.

column6: When he had finished one page he would warm his numb, frozen right hand by the flame of the blazing candles and reach for a new, clean sheet, smooth it with his palm, rule the first line and rapidly fill the page with the large, regular hand-writing used by all officers and non-commisioned officers of the Imperial and Royal Army.
column7: Když dokončí jeden arch, ohřeje si strnulou a prozáblou pravici na plamenu hořících svíček a bere nový, čistý arch, přihladí ho dlaní, táhne první linku a brzy ho vyplňuje velikým pravidelným rukopisem, kterým píší všichni důstojníci a poddůstojníci císařsko - královského vojska.

column6: And when the Lieutenant-Colonel coldly announced that he would apply the Regulations and despatch the insubordinate interpreter to Brod, Rotta found the strength, for the first time, to confront him, openly and brazenly, declaring loudly that the Consul had no such power and that he, Rotta, would perhaps be despatching the Consul a little further than Travnik.
column7: Když podplukovník chladně prohlásil, že uplatní Reglement a neposlušného a rozzuřeného tlumočníka dá dopravit do Brodu, Rotta nalezl v sobě tolik síly, že se s ním poprvé otevřeně a drze střetl, prohlásiv hlasitě, že konzul nemá tu moc a že on, Rotta, dopraví možná konzula z Travniku ještě o kus dále.

column6: As he listened attentively to the speaker with the moustache, a small sallow man, otherwise a modest, timid tailor from the lower bazaar who no one even in his own household had ever heard utter a loud word, suddenly screwed up his eyes, raised his head and bellowed with unexpected power, wildly and hoarsely, as though in revenge for his long silence :

column6: Like the interpreter of the French Consulate, d'Avenat, he too had grown close to the Turks, become used to their customs and ways and to that inhuman life which passed in constant association with the Turks, but at the same time in constant hatred, out-shouting and out-doing them, the rayah of all faiths and travellers of all kinds.
column7: Jako tlumočník francouzského konzulátu ďAvenat, tak i on se sžil s tureckým světem, přivykl jeho obyčejům a způsobům a onomu nelidskému životu, který míjel ve stálém styku s Turky, rájí všech vyznání a cestujícími všeho druhu, ale také v nenávisti, nadutosti a úskocích vůči nim všem.

column6: It seemed to him that the whole Residence was permeated with this stench, like a church with incense, that it clung not only to the people and their clothes, but to the walls and everything within them.

column6: The children of Travnik come into the world with all of this, but above all with a sense of pride.

column6: Pride is their second nature, a vital driving force which accompanies them throughout their lives, marking them out and distinguishing them readily from other people.

column6: Exhausted, poisoned by worries, over-burdened with duties which seemed to him this evening beyond his strength, with bad digestion and insomnia as his only companions, he was sitting motionless over his manuscript when Madame Daville knocked on the door.

column6: And while he lay ill in one of these houses, with no prospect of recovery, without hope that his eyes, which had seen so much of the world, would ever see a broader view than this one, the only thing that could give him a little comfort in his boundless anguish at his premature death and all that he had missed in life, was the thought of the pure beeswax candle which would burn over his grave with a steady, noiseless flame, without smoke or debris.
column7: A když stonal v jednom z těchto domů, bez vyhlídky na uzdravení, bez naděje, že jeho oči, které viděly takový kus světa, ještě kdy uvidí rozhled širší, než je tento, to jediné, co ho v tomto nesmírném žalu z promeškaného života a příliš rané smrti mohlo alespoň trochu potěšit, byla myšlenka na čistý včelí vosk, který mu nad hrobem bude hořet mírným, bezhlasým plamenem, bez kouře a pozůstatků.

column6: Exhausted by the demands made on him by the events of the last months, dissatisfied with the lack of understanding and inadequate support offered him by Paris, General Marmont in Split and the Ambassador in Istanbul, disturbed by the malice and distrust with which the Travnik Turks followed his every step and anything whatever to do with the French, Daville was increasingly conscious of the sad loss of Mehmed Pasha.
column7: Zmučen nápory, které si od něho vyžadovaly události posledních měsíců, nespokojen se špatným porozuměním a nedostatečnou podporou, jichž se mu dostávalo z Paříže, od generála Marmonta ze Splitu a od velvyslance v Cařihradě, zmaten zlobou a nedůvěrou, s jakými travničtí Turci sledovali každý jeho krok a vůbec všechno, co přicházelo od Francouzů, Daville stále tíže pociťoval odchod Mehmed - pašův.

column6: Salomon watched him with his large eyes, constantly perspiring and breathing heavily, as though this was all quite clear to him too, and difficult, just as difficult or even more so than for Daville, as though he fully understood what a torment and a danger all these emperors and kings, viziers and ministers were, whose departures and arrivals did not depend on us in the slightest, but who nevertheless raised us up and cast us down, us and our families, and everything we were and possessed.
column7: Salomon na něho hleděl velikýma očima, stále se potil a těžce dýchal, jako by také jemu to všechno bylo jasné a trapné, stejně trapné nebo ještě trapnější než Davilleovi, jako by plně rozuměl a chápal, jakým trápením a nebezpečím jsou všichni ti císaři a králové, vezírové a ministři, jejichž nástupy a odstupování nikterak nezáleží na nás, ale kteří nás přece jen pozdvihují nebo drtí, nás i naše rodiny i všechno, co jsme a co máme;

column6: And when he stood up, he told himself : it was a black day when you came to this country and now there is no going back, but you must aways keep in mind that you should not judge the actions of these people by your own standards nor react to them with your own sensitivity, otherwise you will come very rapidly to a wretched end.
column7: Když po nemoci vstal, řekl sám sobě : ve zlou chvíli jsi přišel do této země, ale teď není ústupu, nýbrž musíš vždy mít před očima, že jednání těchto lidí nesmíš měřit svou vlastní mírou ani přijímat svou citlivostí, jinak v nejkratší době zahyneš.

column6: He walked about the room, and the meaning of what he had read in von Paulich 's letter began to come clear, provoking ever new waves of mixed emotions : surprise, fear, pity, then a pathetic satisfaction that he and his family had been spared and were alive amid such ruin and upheaval, and then again, uncertainty and alarm.
column7: Procházel se po pokoji a význam toho, co si přečetl v dopisu von Paulichovu, v něm rostl a vyvolával stále nové a nové vlny smíšených pocitů : údivu, strachu, lítosti a pak jakéhosi bědného uspokojení z toho, že on a všichni jeho lidé jsou ušetřeni a živi mezi tolikerými rozvalinami a změnami, a nakonec znovu jakési nejistoty a bázně.

column6: In short, he was sharing the experience of thousands of French people at that time, exhausted in the service of a regime which had in fact been defeated long ago because it had been obliged to ask of people more than they could give.

column6: The very next day Daville received a letter from von Paulich in which he informed him that their two countries were in a state of war and repeated all that they had affirmed verbally about their mutual relations during the course of the war.

column6: And as far as his thoughts could reach : whether he was thinking of the East and the Turks and their way of life without order or stability, therefore without sense or value; or whether he was trying to guess what was going on in France; and what was happening to Napoleon 's army, returning defeated from Russia - everywhere he came up against suffering, misery and dire uncertainty.
column7: A kamkoli sahala jeho mysl, ať uvažovala o Východu a o Turcích a o jejich životě bez řádu a stálosti, tedy bez smyslu a hodnoty, nebo ať se dohadoval, co se děje ve Francii a co s Napoleonem a jeho armádou, která se poražena vrací z Ruska, všude narážel na utrpení, bídu a zlou nejistotu.

column6: Kneeling, her hands clasped, she uttered words he did not know, but which were at that moment clearer to him than his own native tongue : she was imploring him to be kind, to spare her, not to ruin her, because she could not defend herself from what had overcome her as irresistibly as death, but was more difficult and more terrible than death.
column7: Klečíc, se sepjatýma rukama vyslovovala slova, která on neznal, ale která mu v té chvíli byla jasnější než slova jeho mateřštiny : zaklínala ho, aby byl člověkem a aby ji ušetřil, aby ji nepřiváděl do záhuby, neboť ona sama se nemůže bránit tomu, co na ni dolehlo neodolatelně jako smrt, jen těžší a hroznější než smrt.
